branding.name: Top 5 Meal Prep Recipes
branding.tagline: Easy Meal Prep Ideas for a Stress-Free Week

meta.title: Top 5 Meal Prep Recipes | Weekly Meal Prep Made Easy
meta.description: Master meal prep with easy recipes that last all week. Save time, eat healthy, and simplify your life with our top meal prep ideas.

content.heroDescription: We've tested hundreds of recipes to bring you only the top 5. Each one makes 5 perfectly portioned meals that stay fresh all week.
content.itemListName: Top 5 Meal Prep Recipes for Weekly Planning
content.directAnswerTitle: What are the best meal prep recipes?
content.directAnswerText: The best meal prep recipes are those that taste great reheated, store well for 4-5 days, and provide balanced nutrition. Our top 5 meal prep recipes each make 5 servings with clear storage instructions. They're designed to save you time and keep you eating healthy all week.

faq.question: How long does meal prep last in the fridge?
faq.answer: Most meal prep recipes last 4-5 days in the fridge when stored properly in airtight containers. Some dishes freeze well for up to 3 months. Our recipes include specific storage instructions for each dish.

faq.question: What containers are best for meal prep?
faq.answer: Glass containers with locking lids are ideal - they're microwave-safe, don't stain, and last forever. BPA-free plastic containers work too. Look for ones with compartments to keep foods separate.

faq.question: How do I start meal prepping?
faq.answer: Start simple: pick 2-3 recipes, shop on Saturday, and prep on Sunday. Cook proteins in bulk, prepare grains, and chop vegetables. Assembly is fast when components are ready.

faq.question: What foods meal prep well?
faq.answer: Grains (rice, quinoa), roasted vegetables, grilled chicken, ground meat dishes, soups, and stews all meal prep excellently. Avoid foods that get soggy or wilt quickly.

faq.question: Is meal prepping cheaper?
faq.answer: Yes! Meal prepping reduces food waste, prevents impulse takeout orders, and lets you buy in bulk. Most people save $50-100 per week by meal prepping instead of eating out.

guide.metaDescription: Master meal prep: learn storage tips, best containers, foods that prep well, and strategies for eating healthy all week with minimal effort.
guide.heroTitle: Everything you need to know about
guide.heroDescription: Your complete guide to meal prepping: storage tips, best containers, foods that work well, and strategies for a successful meal prep routine.

sections.title: Why meal prep?
sections.content: Meal prepping saves time, money, and stress while helping you eat healthier throughout the week.

items.title: Save time
items.description: Cook once, eat all week - no daily cooking required.

items.title: Save money
items.description: Avoid takeout and reduce food waste by planning ahead.

items.title: Eat healthier
items.description: When healthy meals are ready, you're more likely to eat them.

items.title: Reduce stress
items.description: No more 'what's for dinner' panic - it's already made.

items.title: Portion control
items.description: Pre-portioned meals help you eat the right amount.

items.title: Consistency
items.description: Stay on track with nutrition goals without daily effort.

sections.title: Foods that meal prep well
sections.content: Not all foods are created equal when it comes to meal prep. Here are the best options that stay fresh and taste great reheated:

sections.title: Essential meal prep containers
sections.content: The right containers make meal prep easier and keep food fresher longer:

items.title: Glass containers
items.description: Microwave-safe, don't stain, last forever - the gold standard

items.title: Compartment containers
items.description: Keep foods separate to prevent sogginess

items.title: Mason jars
items.description: Perfect for salads, overnight oats, and soups

items.title: Freezer bags
items.description: Great for portioning proteins and soups for freezing

sections.title: Meal prep success tips
sections.content: Follow these strategies to make your meal prep routine efficient and sustainable.

items.title: Pick a prep day
items.description: Most people prep on Sunday - choose a day that works for your schedule.

items.title: Start simple
items.description: Begin with 3-4 meals before scaling up. Don't overwhelm yourself.

items.title: Batch cook basics
items.description: Cook large batches of grains, proteins, and roasted vegetables to mix and match.

faq.question: How long does meal prep last in the fridge?
faq.answer: Most meal prep recipes last 4-5 days in the fridge when stored properly in airtight containers. Some dishes like soups freeze well for up to 3 months. Always label containers with the date.

faq.question: What are the best meal prep containers?
faq.answer: Glass containers with locking lids are ideal - they're microwave-safe, don't stain, and last for years. BPA-free plastic containers work too. Look for containers with compartments to keep foods separate.

faq.question: How do I start meal prepping?
faq.answer: Start simple: pick 2-3 recipes, shop on Saturday, prep on Sunday. Cook proteins in bulk, prepare grains, and chop vegetables. Assembly is fast when components are ready. Don't try to prep every meal at first.

faq.question: What foods don't meal prep well?
faq.answer: Avoid foods that get soggy (salad with dressing, fried foods, fresh avocado), wilt quickly (delicate greens), or change texture when reheated (scrambled eggs can get rubbery). Add these fresh when eating.

faq.question: How do I reheat meal prep?
faq.answer: Most meals reheat well in the microwave (2-3 minutes). For better results, add a splash of water before reheating and cover loosely. Some foods like grain bowls taste better at room temperature.

recipes.title: Chicken Burrito Bowls
recipes.description: Cilantro lime chicken with seasoned rice, black beans, corn, and all the toppings. Makes 5 perfectly portioned meals for the week.

instructions.instruction: Mix cumin, chili powder, garlic powder, and 1 tsp salt. Rub onto chicken breasts.
Cook rice according to package directions. Fluff with fork, add juice of 1 lime and half the cilantro.
instructions.tip: Chicken broth instead of water makes even better rice.

instructions.instruction: Heat olive oil in a grill pan over medium-high heat. Cook chicken 6-7 minutes per side until internal temp reaches 165°F.
Let chicken rest 5 minutes, then slice into strips.
Season black beans and corn with remaining salt and a squeeze of lime juice.
Divide rice among 5 meal prep containers. Top each with chicken, beans, and corn.
Add salsa and cheese to each container. Store remaining cilantro and lime wedges separately to add fresh before eating.

tips: Stores in the fridge for up to 5 days
Keep salsa and cheese on the side to prevent sogginess

recipes.title: Turkey Meatballs with Vegetables
recipes.description: Juicy Italian turkey meatballs with roasted broccoli and sweet potatoes. A balanced, protein-packed meal that reheats beautifully.

instructions.instruction: Preheat oven to 400°F. Line two sheet pans with parchment paper.
Toss sweet potato cubes with 1 tbsp olive oil, salt, and pepper. Spread on one sheet pan.
Mix turkey, breadcrumbs, egg, parmesan, Italian seasoning, garlic, 0.5 tsp salt, and pepper in a large bowl.
instructions.tip: Don't overmix - it makes meatballs tough.

instructions.instruction: Form into 20 meatballs (about 2 tbsp each). Place on second sheet pan.
Put both pans in oven. Roast sweet potatoes for 30 minutes, meatballs for 20 minutes.
Toss broccoli with remaining olive oil. Add to sweet potato pan for last 15 minutes.
Divide meatballs (4 per container) and vegetables among 5 containers. Store marinara separately.

tips: Use an ice cream scoop for uniform meatballs
Freeze extra meatballs for up to 3 months
Swap broccoli for green beans or asparagus

recipes.title: Greek Chicken Meal Prep
recipes.description: Mediterranean-inspired chicken with cucumber salad, hummus, and warm pita. Fresh flavors that taste great cold or reheated.

instructions.instruction: Marinate chicken: Mix yogurt, juice of 1 lemon, garlic, oregano, and 0.5 tsp salt. Coat chicken and refrigerate at least 30 minutes (or overnight).
Preheat grill or grill pan to medium-high heat. Cook chicken 5-6 minutes per side until charred and cooked through.
Let chicken rest 5 minutes, then slice into strips.
Make cucumber salad: Combine cucumber, tomatoes, red onion, olive oil, remaining lemon juice, and salt.
instructions.tip: Pack salad separately to keep it crisp.

instructions.instruction: Divide chicken among 5 containers. Add cucumber salad to a separate compartment or container.
Add 1/4 cup hummus to each container and top salad with feta.
Store pita breads in separate bags. Warm before serving if desired.

tips: Yogurt marinade keeps chicken incredibly moist
This meal is great cold for hot summer days
Add kalamata olives for extra Greek flavor

recipes.title: Teriyaki Salmon Bowls
recipes.description: Glazed teriyaki salmon over fluffy rice with edamame and pickled vegetables. Restaurant-quality Asian bowls made at home.

instructions.instruction: Make teriyaki sauce: Combine soy sauce, mirin, honey, rice vinegar, ginger, and garlic in a saucepan. Simmer 5 minutes until slightly thickened.
Cook rice according to package directions.
Cook edamame in boiling salted water for 3 minutes. Drain and cool.
Preheat oven to 400°F. Place salmon on a lined baking sheet. Brush with half the teriyaki sauce.
instructions.tip: Reserve half the sauce for serving.

instructions.instruction: Bake salmon for 12-15 minutes until it flakes easily. Brush with more sauce halfway through.
Quick pickle cucumbers: Toss with a splash of rice vinegar and a pinch of salt.
Divide rice among 5 containers. Top with salmon, edamame, and cucumber. Drizzle with remaining sauce. Garnish with sesame seeds and green onions.

tips: Salmon reheats best at 50% power in the microwave
Store sauce separately to prevent rice from getting soggy
Sub brown rice or cauliflower rice for lower carbs

recipes.title: Vegetable Fried Rice Bowls
recipes.description: Better than takeout fried rice loaded with vegetables and eggs. Budget-friendly meal prep that uses up whatever veggies you have.

instructions.instruction: Heat 1 tbsp vegetable oil in a large wok over high heat. Scramble eggs until just set. Remove and chop roughly.
Add remaining vegetable oil to wok. Add broccoli and bell pepper. Stir-fry 3 minutes.
instructions.tip: Work in batches if your wok isn't large enough.

instructions.instruction: Add frozen peas and carrots. Cook 2 minutes until heated through.
Add garlic and ginger. Stir-fry 30 seconds until fragrant.
Add cold rice, breaking up any clumps. Spread in wok and let sit 1 minute to get crispy, then stir.
Pour soy sauce and sesame oil around the edges of the wok. Toss everything together.
Add eggs back, season with white pepper, and toss with green onions. Divide among 5 containers.

tips: Day-old rice is essential - fresh rice will be mushy
A hot wok and working quickly gives the best results
Add chicken, shrimp, or tofu for more protein
